Award.AwardTitle: Gordon Research Conference, Thalamocortical Interactions: Cell and Circuit Properties. Meeting, February 14-19, 2016, Ventura, CA
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will provide support to US-based students and post-doctoral fellows and junior scientists to attend the 2016 Gordon Research Conference on Thalamocortical Interactions. This five-day meeting will be the first to bring together researchers to present results and enagage in discussions on the cell and circuit properties of thalamocortical interactions, and build on these to explore their roles in cognition and behavior. This conference represents a rare opportunity for neuroscientists interested in thalamocortical interactions to exchange new results, hypotheses, and ideas at many levels, from cellular through systems to cognitive
and clinical. This is especially timely because this field has been expanding significantly with the recent appreciation that the thalamus plays an ongoing and critical role in cortical functioning.

The intellectual merit of this meeting derives from its small size, which promotes interactions between participants, and the assembly of many top scientists whose research spans thalamocortical interactions across multiple sensory modalities, emphasizing the commonalities. This combination leads to fruitful comparative analyses, raises new questions about underlying mechanisms and often leads to new collaborations. By maximizing both formal discussion and informal interactions, the Gordon Conference will highlight exciting new developments that have implications both for a basic understanding of the emergent properties of neural circuits as well as pathologies that involve thalamocortical disruptions. With respect to broader impacts, this meeting will benefit the larger community in multiple ways. First, it will help train and inspire the next generation of scientists by exposing students and postdoctoral fellows to exciting science and scientists. Second, special emphasis will be given to junior faculty. Finally, a concerted effort will be made to recruit scientists from under-represented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Gordon Research Conference on Thalamocortical Interactions was held from February 14-19, 2016 at the Ventura Beach Marriott in Ventura, California. The meeting had 108 in attendance.  Scientists from academia represented 97% of the participants while attendees from government accounted for 3%. The meeting also attracted a strong mix of young investigators and senior scientists.  Students and post-docs accounted for 34% of all attendees. Approximately 38% of the participants at the 2016 meeting were women. The meeting brought together experimentalists and theoreticians at all career stages, from pre- and postdoctoral fellows to assistant and full professors, to present and discuss the latest advances in our understanding of the organization, development, function, and plasticity of thalamocortical networks, and the impact of disease on thalamocortical interactions. A particular strength of the conference was the cross talk and discussion that was emphasized and generated between basic-science and clinical researchers studying thalamocortical interactions at different spatial and temporal scales as well as across different sensory, motor and cognitive modalities.

Participants had an opportunity to provide feedback at the end of the Conference. The feedback collected from the meeting was extremely positive. Evaluations included numerous positive remarks regarding the diverse collection of topics and speakers, the high quality of the talks and the discussions at the sessions.
